awd_titl_txt: Full waveform modeling and inversion of seismic attenuation and application to characterizing near-surface fractures at Susquehanna Shale Hills Critical Zone Observatory
awd_abstract_narration:
Seismologists often use seismic waves to study the Earth's interior. This is because seismic wave properties are very sensitive to the physical and chemical state of the Earth, from the shallow to the deep Earth. This project explores one such property, seismic attenuation, which is considered to be a direct indicator for temperature of the Earth with depth, as well as the presence of fluids. Because of its multi-purpose use, a map of this property in Earth structure can improve our understanding of how the Earth's interior works. The main goal of this project is to develop a method to image seismic attenuation using seismic waves. Broader impacts include the mentoring of a postdoctoral researcher at Penn State University and the development of new methods for the scientific community to use.

Measurements of seismic wave attenuation potentially provide valuable source of information about the physical and chemical state of the Earth's interior. Seismic full waveform inversion (FWI) as a promising measurement tool for inverting Q still has several key issues to be investigated: 1) whether or not the existing fractional anelastic wave equation, that separates amplitude absorption and phase dispersion, can facilitate the development of FWI; 2) explicit Q embedded in fractional anelastic wave equations will simplify the computations of gradient; 3) how cross-talks between velocity and Q in FWI could be alleviated. To address these issues, this project will conduct three main tasks. First, starting from the newly developed fractional anelastic wave equation that parameterize an explicit Q,  a Q-FWI method will be developed using adjoint-state approaches. Second, a suitable inversion strategy for multi-parameters (velocity and Q) will be sought. Third, the Q-FWI will be validated using synthetic near-surface geological models.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Seismologists use seismic waves to study the Earth interior because seismic wave properties (seismic velocity and attenuation) are very sensitive to the physical and chemical state of the Earth interior from shallow to deep earth. For example, seismic attenuation is considered to be one direct indicator for temperature with depth (e.g. mantle melting), the existence of fluids, and fault/fracture dynamics (open or closure, dry or fluid-filled?) in the Earth interior. Therefore, advancing our ability to map/image attenuation in Earth structure can significantly improve our understanding of mantle structure and dynamics, subsurface porous media, fluid properties in geosystems, and fault/fracture zones.

This project developed a new theoretical framework of the seismic full waveform inversion (FWI) for inverting seismic attenuation properties of geologic targets. We started to derive a time-domain formulation of the anelastic wave equation, where the power terms of fractional Laplacian operators are spatially independent. Starting from the new anelastic wave equation, we developed the FWI method using adjoint-state approaches. We experimented the suitable inversion strategy for multi-parameters (velocity and Q) FWI. Then, we validated the FWI method using synthetic near-surface geological models. Finally, we applied this method to existing field datasets from recent active-source near-surface seismic surveys in the Susquehanna Shale Hills Critical Zone Observatory (SSHCZO) site (State College, PA) for quantifying the fault/fracture zones in the bedrock with seismic attenuation models.

The importance of the research is both fundamental and practical. The outcome of this project provided a new theoretical framework of a practical fractional viscoelastic wave equation that is fundamentally important for studying seismic wave propagation in the Earth. The new FWI methodology based on a fractional wave equation will offer new opportunities to study the challenging multiparameter FWI problem. The FWI method will also advance our ability to tomographically image the subsurface attenuation structure for more accurate predictions of the attenuation properties of shallow bedrock fractures at the SSHCZO site. Ultimately, the high-resolution attenuation model obtained for the SSHCZO offered new geophysical insights of near-surface fracture zones and thus permeability and/or flowpaths at the SSHCZO.

This project trained one Ph.D. student and a postdoc researcher. We published our results in five peer-reviewed journal papers. Ph.D. student's work made of the PhD dessertation on seismic attenuation modeling and full waveform inversion. This project supported the development of an open-source software package of seismic FWI, which will be distributed to the community. We already incorporated the project outcomes to a graduate student course "Computational Seismology" at Penn State. We designed the handson exercises for students to learn seismic wave propagation and FWI in the real Earth media.

 


Last Modified: 10/06/2022
Modified by: Tieyuan Zhu
